Award.AwardTitle: Evaluation of the Cognitive, Psychometric, and Instructional Affordances of Curriculum-Embedded Assessments: A Comprehensive Validity-Based Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF DR-K12 project falls within the category of Applied Research: Evaluative Studies of NSF Funded Resources and Tools. The overarching goal of this project is to evaluate the assessment components embedded within two NSF-supported mathematics curricula: Everyday Mathematics and Math Trailblazers. The investigators will apply a comprehensive validity perspective that integrates a variety of empirical evidence regarding the cognitive, psychometric, and instructional affordances of multiple assessments embedded in these curricula as part of their overall instructional design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had the goal of improving our practical and theoretical understandings of standards-driven elementary school mathematics curricula by investigating their embedded assessments and evaluating their structure and role within the curriculum. We focused on three fundamental questions: (a) what constitutes high quality curriculum-embedded assessment in K-8 school mathematics, (b) how does it support student learning in an ongoing instructional process tied to nationally defined standards (NCTM, 2000; CCSM, 2010), and (c) what do teachers need to know to make effective use of such assessments in their practice? To address these issues we focused on collection of multiple types of classroom data and in-depth analyses of a substantial subset of assessment cases embedded within the Everyday Mathematics (EM) and Math Trailblazers (MTB) curricula. The project specifically focused on Grade 4 materials and applied our validity analysis framework to the two different curricula.

Among the Project’s key outcomes is articulation of a validity framework for classroom assessments that includes three primary components: (1) cognitive validity, (2) instructional validity, and (3) inferential validity. This framework guided the analysis of the assessments embedded in these two grade 4 mathematics curricula and it has also been applied to designs for the validation of other assessments designed to function in the classroom to support instruction. Multiple forms of data were gathered to provide converging evidence regarding each of the three forms of validity. To concentrate time and resources, we focused our investigation on three centrally important content strands at the fourth grade, Number & Numeration (NN), Operations & Computation (OC), and Patterns, Functions & Algebra (PFA).

Our work shows that constructing a validity argument for curriculum embedded assessments poses a significant challenge. This is attributable to the complexity of assessment in curricula such as those studied. Such complexity comes from the number and types of assessments of student learning that are included as part of ongoing instruction as well as their intended uses. Any given assessment activity or class of activities needs to be evaluated in terms of all three components of validity -- cognitive, instructional, and inferential as laid out in our validity analysis framework. As might be expected, many of the assessment activities show evidence of instructional validity in the sense that they are closely tied to the underlying mathematics content goals of the instructional program and the sequence in which instruction unfolds related to those goals. But it was seldom that strong evidence was found regarding all three components of the validity of any assessment activity.

There are three broad implications from this work. First, these investigations have made clear the central importance of embedded assessments and their intended and enacted roles to curricular structure and goals. Second, given the variety of types of assessments, the scope of learning within a given school year, the interactions among curriculum, goals and teacher instructional and assessment practice, this work underscores both the importance of a multilevel data collection design and reveals some ways in which future research could be designed to be more efficient. Third, the overall results suggest that there is considerable room for improvement in the design and enactment of curriculum embedded assessment with respect to all three critical components of validity. Even so, both curricular programs have tried to develop comprehensive and useful assessment tools to support teacher instruction practice.
